The goal of the Integrated Family Planning and Reproductive Health Project for Improved Health and Quality of Life (IFPRH project) is to increase the use of modern family planning methods in in 15 districts in Zambia. This project is premised on the notion that improved family planning service delivery, combined with stronger and more accountable institutions, and increased awareness of healthy family planning and reproductive health practices, will improve the health status and quality of life of the Zambian population. The IFPRH project will help the Ministry of Community Development Maternal and Child Health (MCDMCH) play a leadership role in developing a strengthened, community-based family planning service delivery system. A key project outcome will be the development of a “Model District-Community Family Planning Service Delivery System,” in approximately 15 districts to be selected by the Ministry. USAID defines such a system as one that encompasses the key components and systems needed, at the community level, to respond effectively to the family planning needs of the population. These systems could include systems to support: trained providers, expanded method mix, client-centered care, client feedback, outreach to vulnerable populations particularly the youth, contraceptive commodities and supplies, supervision, mentoring, behavior change communication, public-private partnerships, innovation and learning, Family Planning High Impact Practices, data collection, and other components. Key project activities are fully aligned with the USAID/Zambia Project Appraisal Document (PAD), FY 2014-2018. This project is also aligned with the priorities of the Government of Zambia’s FP2020 National Strategic Plan for Family Planning.
